transcripts.text: The scale of the corruption of the American electoral system is so vast that we have to break it down into several pieces and examine them one by one. So exhibit one.  On November 8th, 2020, ABC News chief anchor George Stephanopoulos interviewed Republican Governor Kristi Noem on ABC's This Week.

Governor Noem, thanks for joining us this morning.  COVID is rising in your state as well.  Cases are up, hospitalizations are up, deaths are up.  Are you prepared to work with President-elect Biden to get it under control?

Okay, whoa, whoa, stop right there.  The term president-elect has a specific legal definition defined by Article 2, Section 1, Clause 2 of the U.S.  Constitution, as well as the 12th and 20th amendments to the U.S.  Constitution, which calls for an election day to be held, quote, in each state on the Tuesday after the first Monday in November every fourth year.  Now, in 2020, that was November 3rd.  That is when the people of each state are polled, but the actual election of the president, legally defined, has always occurred on the Monday after the second Wednesday in December, when the various state electors convene in Washington to actually elect the president.  In the year 2020, that's December 14th.  Now, on that day, the candidate with 270 votes or more is elected president and becomes president-elect from that moment until the inauguration of the president on January 20th, unless January 20th should fall on a Sunday, in which case Inauguration Day becomes January 21st.  Before the electors convene to vote, Joe Biden is not president-elect.  Between now and December 14th, the specific constitutional term for Joe Biden is just some guy.  Right now, I am legally as president-elect as he is, and so are you.  Now, at 4.30 p.m.  on Election Day, the New York Times issued the following tweet, quote, The role of declaring the winner of a presidential election falls to the news media.  The broadcast networks and cable news outlets have vowed to be prudent.  Here's how it will work.  This isn't just incorrect, and it isn't just fraudulent.  It's the declaration of a coup d'etat.  The media does not select the president.  The fact that the New York Times said such a thing means that millions and millions of people have come to believe that that's how things actually work.  Now, you think I'm overstating the case when I say it's a coup?  Think about it this way.  What if he'd written, the role of declaring the winner of a presidential election falls to the National Rifle Association.  Now, pay attention, because here's how it's going to go.  The instant that George Stephanopoulos referred to Joe Biden as the president-elect, he was fraudulently asserting something that he knew not to be true.  He knows full well that legal challenges have been made during this election.  George Stephanopoulos knows exactly how things work because George Stephanopoulos ran Bill Clinton's successful 1992 campaign along with James Carville. I've spoken with Republican secretaries of state in Georgia, in Arizona.  I've spoken to Republican officials across the country.  They have come up with zero evidence of widespread fraud.
